item.title: UK virus-tracing app switches to Apple-Google model
item.description: Government now intends to launch an app in the autumn but it may still lack contact-tracing tech.

item.title: Dame Vera Lynn: Royalty and Sir Paul McCartney lead tributes
item.description: The Queen and Sir Paul pay their respects to the Forces' Sweetheart, who has died aged 103.

item.title: Facebook removes Trump ad over 'Nazi hate symbol'
item.description: The tech giant says a campaign ad featuring a red triangle used in Nazi Germany violated its policy.

item.title: Trump's bid to end Obama-era immigration policy ruled unlawful
item.description: US Supreme Court rules against the president's bid to end Obama-era programme that protects children.

item.title: Boris Johnson welcomes Emmanuel Macron for talks and flypast
item.description: The leaders mark 80 years since a BBC broadcast in which France was urged to keep fighting Hitler.

item.title: Nurse Neomi Bennett 'racially profiled' in arrest
item.description: British Empire Medal recipient Neomi Bennett overturned her conviction for obstructing police.

item.title: Coronavirus: Baby aged 13 days dies with Covid-19
item.description: The baby's death is announced as Sheffield Children's Hospital confirms a child died there on Monday.

item.title: Coronavirus: Almost 100 staff at food factories test positive
item.description: The staff work at two different companies which supply food to hospitals, shops and restaurants.

item.title: 'Sizeable increase' in Leicester coronavirus cases
item.description: Leicester sees hundreds of confirmed cases in two weeks, while an outbreak in Yorkshire is reported.

item.title: Coronavirus: One in four infected by virus cannot be reached
item.description: Latest performance comes as government surveillance suggests falling rates of infection slowing.

item.title: Election 2019: New leader not enough to win again, Labour warned
item.description: Labour has a "mountain to climb" to regain power, a major review of its 2019 election defeat says.

item.title: Pub chain 'has no choice' but to open on 4 July
item.description: The boss of Oakman Inns says that if pubs don't reopen "they'll continue to bleed cash".

item.title: Black Lives Matter: Raab criticised over 'Game of Thrones' comment
item.description: The foreign secretary says he has "full respect" for Black Lives Matter after backlash over comments.

item.title: Royal Ascot: Fans dress up at home for Ladies' Day
item.description: Those missing out on the horse racing in person are making the best of it by dressing up for charity.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: Statues are falling but what should replace them?
item.description: There are calls to take down tributes to proponents of slavery across the UK. What should come next?

item.title: Six movies resuming production after coronavirus
item.description: It could be Mission Impossible to get these movies out in time, but they are gonna give it a shot...

item.title: Coronavirus: How charity shops are handling the nation's spring clean
item.description: How charity shop staff are preparing to be on the receiving end of the great Covid clearout.

item.title: Coronavirus: Care home creates garden visits
item.description: A care home is reuniting loved ones with socially distanced garden visits for residents and family.

item.title: Last of Us Part 2: Creators say diversity in games ‘essential’
item.description: Newsbeat's gaming reporter Steffan Powell speaks to the director and lead actor of 2020's most anticipated video game

item.title: Coronavirus: 'We need a designated shielding hour'
item.description: Natasha Howard is campaigning for a set time in the day when only people who are shielding go outdoors.

item.title: The 101-year-old who was once Charles de Gaulle's chauffeur
item.description: When she was 21, Olivia Jordan found herself driving the resistance leader Charles de Gaulle around London.

item.title: University deadline day: 'Covid has changed my whole future'
item.description: Video lectures and no freshers' week make for tough decisions

item.title: Ibiza: Nightclubs will 'not open this year'
item.description: Local media reports clubs may stay shut until we have an effective coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: What happened when a city disbanded its police force
item.description: Camden, New Jersey, created a brand new police force to forge better ties with the community.

item.title: Coronavirus: What will happen to pets after lockdown?
item.description: Many people brought pets into their lives during lockdown. A pet behaviourist explains how animals will react to their owners' return to work.

item.title: We'll Meet Again: The story of Dame Vera Lynn's wartime classic
item.description: The song was one of the first to feature a synth, was accused of being too "slushy" for the troops.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: Where does 'taking a knee' come from?
item.description: Taking the knee is one of the symbols of the Black Lives Matter movement. Why?

item.title: John Bolton: Ten biggest claims in his Donald Trump book
item.description: The White House is trying to stop its release, but extracts have already been widely published.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'My employer broke the furlough rules'
item.description: The tax office has had thousands of complaints, some from staff who have been made to work while on furlough.

item.title: Analysis: Labour's electoral mountain
item.description: A review into the party's performance at the polls says woes did not start and end with Jeremy Corbyn.

item.title: Coronavirus: They've worked for years, but still miss out on furlough
item.description: What's life like for people missing out on government payments during lockdown?

item.title: Gretna Green: The wedding capital where no-one can get married
item.description: Gretna Green usually hosts more than 3,000 marriages every year - but has been like a "ghost town" during lockdown.

item.title: Spurs 'not in same league' as other clubs in summer transfer market - Mourinho
item.description: Jose Mourinho says Tottenham are not going to be "in the same world" as other Premier League clubs in this summer's transfer market.

item.title: Paul Pogba: Man Utd boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer looking for leadership from midfielder
item.description: Manchester United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer wants to see some leadership on the pitch from record signing Paul Pogba.

item.title: Liverpool to wrap up title? Lawro takes on Sports Team drummer Al Greenwood
item.description: Mark Lawrenson takes on Sports Team drummer Al Greenwood to make predictions for this weekend's Premier League fixtures.

item.title: RFU reviewing singing of Swing Low, Sweet Chariot song
item.description: The Rugby Football Union (RFU) is reviewing England fans' use of Swing Low, Sweet Chariot, saying many do not know about its links with slavery.

item.title: Referees' body to review goalline technology error that denied Sheff Utd
item.description: Premier League referees will review the goalline technology error that denied Sheffield United a goal in their draw at Aston Villa, BBC Sport understands.

item.title: Royal Ascot: Stradivarius and Frankie Dettori land third successive Gold Cup victory
item.description: Superstar stayer Stradivarius, ridden by Frankie Dettori, wins a third successive Gold Cup at Royal Ascot.

item.title: Benzema moves ahead of Puskas in style as Real win
item.description: Karim Benzema moves fifth on Real Madrid's all-time leading goalscorer list with a double in a victory over Valencia.

item.title: How does breakthrough coronavirus drug work?
item.description: A cheap steroid is hailed a big breakthrough in the treatment of seriously ill Covid-19 patients.

item.title: Could creating billions of pounds save your job?
item.description: The Bank of England has unveiled new measures to stimulate the economy. How do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: What's the risk for ethnic minorities?
item.description: Statistics from England show more people from BAME backgrounds are dying than those from white ethnic groups.

item.title: How many cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People at risk of becoming severely ill if they get coronavirus advised to take extra precautions.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do I have to go back to work after lockdown?
item.description: With lockdown restrictions eased, people are starting to go back to work. But what are your rights?

item.title: Where can I go on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Has a second wave of infections hit Iran?
item.description: Iran was one of the worst affected countries early on, so is the virus flaring up again?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's happening to free school meals this summer?
item.description: The government in England will now provide free school meals vouchers over the summer holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: How to keep safe while shopping in a coronavirus pandemic
item.description: From one way systems to not touching everything on the shelves - shopping looks very different.

item.title: What shops are open?
item.description: Non-essential shops have reopened in England, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus: What will clothes shopping look like?
item.description: From Monday all non-essential shops are allowed to reopen in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing to help single people cut off from family and friends.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Nine million people have accessed the scheme, which will move to its next phase in July.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are going back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Can I stay with my boyfriend now? And other questions
item.description: Questions about support bubbles, and other coronavirus topics

item.title: Coronavirus: Five ways shopping will be different from now on
item.description: Shops in England are preparing to welcome customers back but what will the "new normal" look like?

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: The first "support bubbles" of people who can meet indoors has been announced in England and Northern Ireland.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
item.description: The world faces the worst recession for 80 years. But what does that mean?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, bars, cafes and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Pubs and restaurants in England are expected to reopen in July, but can I meet a friend for a meal?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: Five unanswered questions on the travel quarantine rules
item.description: Travellers to the UK now have to self-isolate for 14 days. But how will the rules work in practice?

item.title: When can I ride an e-scooter legally?
item.description: With people told to avoid public transport, the government's hoping to trial e-scooter rental schemes.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: Saffron Walden dentist shows new appointment routine
item.description: Join us on a walk through a dental surgery to show what you might face at your next appointment.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: The blogger who hit back against a hammer-wielding Russian ‘assassin’
item.description: Tumso Abdurakhmanov says Russia's security service must have helped Chechens plan an attempt to assassinate him.
